Fingerprinting approaches are THE ONLY PRACTICALLY FEASIBLE approaches for nxn plagiarism discovery
problem of fingerprinting: only a small fraction of chunks is actually useful in identifying derivation, but fingerprinting approaches can usually not detct which
heuristic chunk selection tends to be (very) lossy depending on the selection strategy
suffix trees or phrase-based collections are other tools that guarantee identification of unique chunks, but both are way to storage requirement
proposed SPEX algorithm for lossless chunk selection:
1st pass scanning of all docs hashing each word to an index
2nd pass scanning of all docs each 2-word chunk whose 1-word-chunks are both already in the index is hashed to the index, all others are discarded
3rd pass scanning of all docs each 3-word chunk is concidered IF both distinct 2-word-chunks are in the index ELSE discarded
n>3 pass analogue -> always 2 distinct sub-chunks with length n-1 and one word overlap
after nth pass, depending on desired chunk size, index of shared chunks is created

mation  interests

bution  of texts  to  groups  or  individu- 
als

Part 2: How effective are standard user
modelling approaches applied to mind maps?

children.nodeText: User Modeling describes the ability of a computer system to adopt to a user's needs and wants based on their special characteristics

User Modeling describes the ability of a system to make observations
about a user and to use these observations to adapt the experience to better
meet the user’s wants or needs
Users may differ by various factors, mainly by their demographics and background data, goals and plans to achieve these goals, by their knoweldge and preferences, and some external factors
Demographic data and their background information may be suited to distingish users
user segmentation can be done based on
this includes the classic demographic data such as age and gender
but it also includes socio-economic factors such as income and class;
psychographic factors such as life styles and values;
and physical and psychological chracteristics such as attitude and disabilities
For instance, for elderly users it might be appropriate for a system to use larger font sizes
If a system wants to recommend travel recommendations, user's income might be an important factor to find relevant travel destinations
goals, and plans to achieve these goals
goals and plans to achieve these goals may distinguish users
general assumption in user modeling: a user has goals and plans to achieve these goals
Goals may be ambitious such as writting a dissertation or rather small such as writing an assignment
there is lots of literature on goal and plan recognition (todo)
Another important factor that may distinguish computer users is their knowledge
Often the literature speaks about "interests" that distinduish users
It is difficult to distinguish between goals, knowledge and interests
Finally, some user modelling systems consider time, place and the device a user is using as additional factors that should be considered in a user model
model of input factors for (paper) recommendations
The fact that computer users differ by their demographics, goals, knowledge and external factors, has led to many types of applications adopting to the users' differences
The reasons why computer systems and services need to know about users' differences are manyfold
Korbs 1993 lists ten application areas in which user modells are used to provide user specific services and systems
and a look to other research papers, shows even further areas
adaptive hypermedia can be used in
user models have been used for predictions in the field of
perform actions on behalf of users
list of various web personalization applications (no recommender)
However, overall there are three main application areas for which user models are required: Human Computer Interaction; User Prediction Tasks; and Information Filtering/Retrieval
In the field of Human Computer Interaction (HCI), user models are utilized for adaptive interfaces, navigation and presentation
For instance, the presentation of a software might change, depending on the user's age
For elderly users, larger fonts might be used, for younger users, smaller fonts
Some software also offers "advanced" modi for so called power-users, users with high computer and domain knowledge;
Another simple example is Windows 7's start menu - programs that are frequently opened are automaticaly "pinned" to it, for fast access
user models may be used to create "self-customizing" software
Some research fields are concerned with the prediction of what a user will do next (and how good he will do it)
user model for predicting further customer purchases
probablistic approach that can predict a users next command line command
80% accuracy if first character is known
approach is based only on analysing touples of commands / the last command (strong focus on very recent past activity)
only slight improvements with far more complex models (2nd)
user models have been used for command-line predictions (2nd)
Of course this is also an example for HCI which shows that the areas overlap
Thirdly, in information retrieval, and especially information filtering, user models play an important role
In all fields of information filtering the main question is: wich items are relevant for a certain user?
That means, the system must know what a user's (information) needs are and how good items would satisfy this need
Formally there is a number of users and a number of items
the system calculates the relevance of each item for each individual user
Usually, all items exeeding a certain threshold are shown to the user
Figure: Basic Concept of user Modelling
Although there are many variations, only two main approaches are used
In personalized search, a search engines does not only take into account the current search query but further  information about the user as well
Most recommender systems utilize user profiles to recommend new items to their users

Computer systems which want to adopt to their users' differences, need to somehow know what the users' characteristics are
In general, user profiles can be created and maintained manually by the users themselves, or automatically by a user modelling system
user data can be collected explictely or implicitly
The probably most apparent option to obtain the required information about a user is to ask him (or obtain the information from a third party if this party has the information already)
Personalization can be user driven (user provides input)
Early expert systems, for example, asked their users to specify their skills
Also today, many systems let users specify their demographics, skills, etc.
A popular example are social business networks like LinkedIn or XING
On these plattforms users can specify their "wants" and "haves" with keywords
There are several advantages of this approach
It is rather easy to implement
The develop only needs an interface to ask the user and a way to store the data
Manual data also gives full controll to the user
For some applications the user might not want to have information automatically collected
This might be the case, especially if the information of the user model is publicly available
For instance, in social networks, instead of asking the user, the "want's" could be automamtically determined by monitoring search queries of the user

However, besides the fact, that social networks usually have no access to a user's search queries e.g. on Google, most users probably would not their search queries being displayed publicly in their profile
in most cases users have no incentive to maintain their user profiles
and sometimes they even don't know exactly what they want
As shown later, some systems combine the automatic collection of data with manuall data collection
Creating user models can be done automatically
That is "inferring unobservable information about a user from observable information about him/her"

User modeling involves inferring unobservable information about a user from
observable information about him/her, e.g. his/her actions or utterances
That means, making assumptions e.g. about the users' interests and knowledge based on some other information known about the users
In information retrieval and filtering content based filtering and collaborative filtering is used
There are three approaches to obtain information about a user than can be used to infer further information
Monitoring of Usage of a system / Behaviour
One approach is to monitor how a user is using a computer system
For instance, which documents he opens, how fast he is typing, which entries in the menu he selects and so on
Linked Items (content based)  / factual item information
To identify interests and knowledge of a user, often content of items that are somehow connected to the user are analysed
It is assumed that the content of connected items describe the interests and knowledge of the users
For instance, if a user owns many books (<-item) about mind maps (<-content), a user modelling system would assume that the user is interested in mind mapping
The challenge of this approach lies in finding out that e.g. a book is about mind maps
the type of items being analysed is manifold
often textual items are analysed because these are comparatively easy for computers to analyse and understand
all the following items have been utilized by user modelling systems
but also the content of non-textual items such as movies and music has been utilized
The way items may be "connected" to a user are manifold, too

Collaborative filtering does not aim at finding a users' knowledge, nor goals, nor ...
The aim of CF is simply to create a detailed user profile including the items a user has rated
That means, with CF, the system cannot say "user A likes mind maps" or "user A probably will perform action Y next"
The system can only say "user A likes item A, and B and C" and maybe the system knows the user does not like other items, and maybe also how much the user likes the items
Which items the user likes play no role in Collaborative filtering
the user profile in this case usually is a simple matrix containing all users and all items with their ratings
ratings do not neccesarrily have to be "real" explicit ratings
many systems also use implicit ratings, that is the systems assume a rating based on some actions the user performed
these action can be the same as those used in content based filtering for establishing a connection between a user and an item
For instance, the academic recommender system of CiteSeer has a list of actions a user may perform
user action that could be taken for build a user profile
Why this can be usefull is explained in 1.2.3

Stereotyping is one of the oldest approaches in user modelling
Based on some known facts, new information is infered based on stereotype assumptions
For instance, if a user modelling system knows that a user is male, 45 years old, has two children, and is married, the system could assume that the user is rather conservative
Instead of demographic data, also observed actions may be analysed
For instance, if the system observes that a user has a high typing speed on the keyboard, it could concluded that the user is a secretary, or maybe an author
As with stereotypes in real live, the disadvantage of this system is, that they often might be true but there are many exceptions to the rule and users might feel insulted
The sterotype usually can also not create individual user profiles but just segment users into groups of similar users
As the stereotyping approach usually is based on demographic data, it is not relevant for this thesis
For instance, professors, postdocs, graduate students, undergraduate students
each subgroup has different characteristics and in turn different needs

The only mind mapping software companies who have at least done some kind of user modeling are MindMeister and Mindomo
MindMeister is a web based mind mapping application that allows users to create mind maps in their web browser
Between 200x and 200y personlized advertisement was displayed in the free version of MindMeister
Whenever a user edited a node in a mind map, text of that node was send to Amazons Webservice
Amazon's Webservice then returned book recommendations relevant to the submitted text and MindMeister displayed this recommendation in their software
The node selected in the mind map contains the text "Collaborative Filtering Recommender" and in the right panel, books are recommended for recommender systems
Similarily, Mindomo, a web based mind mapping application, too, displayed personalized advertisement to its users
mindomo used google adwords for personlized advertisement
Mindomo did not use the text of a single node and Amazon's Webservice but Mindomo used Google Adwords instead
Usually, companies can book advertisement and specifiy a list of keywords that describe the ad
When a user is searching on Google for a term that is assigned to an ads, this advertisement is displayed
Here it was searched for the term "mind map" and on the right part of the page, Google displays Advertisement from products related to mind maps

According to an email from Mindomo, they specified a set of fixed keywords (among others project management, planning, and brainstorming) and Google delivered advertisement relevent to these keywords, that was then displayed in Mindomo's mind mapping software
Today, neither MindMeister nor Mindomo are displaying advertisement any more in their applications
On request, both companies did not want (or could not) provide any specific numbers.
However, Mindomo states that "people were not really interested" in the ads and results were "mediocre"
mindomo used google adwords for personlized advertisement
and simply the fact that MindMeister removed the advertisement shows that it probably did not pay off

This assumption sounds plausible but if Mindomo is the one specifying just a small set of keywords, there probably was low variety in the advertisement

One of the earliest document models was a boolean model
In this model it was only stored whether a term occured in a document or not

use of index enhances search capabilities

"posting" tells in which documents a term occurs

inverted index is without rivals as the most efficient structure for ad hoc text search
There was a need for ranked retrieval, i.e. weighting documents according to a given query
nowerdays, the vector space model is the most commen model in information retrieval to represent textual items
It stores a document as a number of vectors, where each vector represents a term of the document
In contrast to the boolean model, each term has a weight that describes how well this term describes the document it occurs in
That means a system cannot only say "this document is (not) relevant for a given term or user model" but it can say how relevant a document is in comparison to other documents
The idea to represent a document based on weighted term vectors was first published by Luhn 1957

The ﬁrst ideas for a text representation based on weighted term vectors were already put
forward in the late 1950s by Luhn (1957)
However, it was not before 19xx, when Salton introduced his TF-IDf formula, the idea of weighted term vectors started to become popular

Cornell University

A term that occurs frequently in a document does not discriminate well if this term occurs frequently in all (or most) documents of a collection
This becomes clear especially with so-called "stop words"
Stop words are words like "the", a", "of", "and" and so on that occur in basically every english text very frequently
Thefore, a good vector space model gives a high weight to terms in a document that do occur frequently in that document but seldom in other documents
To increase performance, stop words usually are removed completely from the documents for indexing
document frequency is the number of documents containing a term

The first instance-based technique capable of handling concept drift is IB3 (Aha et 
al.,  1991)

IB3 was criticized as it is able to adapt to gradual 
concept  drifts  only,  and  its  adaptation  is  relatively  slow

Local  Weighted  Forgetting  (LWF)  of  Salganicoff    (1997)  deactivates  old  instances, 
but  only  when  similar  new  instances  appear

Prediction  Error  Context  Switching 
(PECS)  is  similar to  LWF, but it  takes  into account the classification  accuracy of an 
instance also, and is able to store instances for further reactivating (Salganicoff, 1997).

PECS and LWF were shown to perform better than a simple window-based technique 
TWF, and PECS was the best technique overall.
